content.title: Great Saphenous Vein Anatomy
content.definition: The longest vein in the body, extending from the medial malleolus to the saphenofemoral junction, representing the primary superficial venous drainage of the lower extremity.

concepts.definition: The anatomic pathway of the great saphenous vein.

clinical_features.origin: Anterior to medial malleolus, dorsal venous arch
clinical_features.leg: Ascends along medial leg, crosses knee posteromedially
clinical_features.thigh: Courses along medial thigh in saphenous compartment
clinical_features.termination: Saphenofemoral junction at fossa ovalis, ~4cm inferior to inguinal ligament

concepts.definition: The fascial space containing the GSV.

clinical_features.boundaries: Saphenous fascia superficially, deep fascia deep
clinical_features.saphenous_eye: Ultrasound appearance of compartment with vein
clinical_features.clinical_significance: Distinguishes true GSV from accessory veins

concepts.definition: Named branches joining the great saphenous vein.

clinical_features.anterior_accessory: AASV - lateral to GSV in thigh
clinical_features.sfj_tributaries: Superficial epigastric, superficial circumflex iliac, external pudendal

clinical_features.sfj_location: 3-4 cm inferior and lateral to pubic tubercle
clinical_features.valves: 7-9 valves typically, terminal valve at SFJ
clinical_features.saphenous_nerve: Courses adjacent to GSV below knee - high risk zone

clinical_features.conduit_use: Preferred conduit for coronary and peripheral bypass
clinical_features.ablation_target: Primary target in superficial venous insufficiency treatment

sources.reference: Caggiati A et al. J Vasc Surg. 2002;36:416-422
Cavezzi A et al. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 2006;32:462-468
